It's not overly rich or sweet, and the feel is sort of sinewy. Seems more about size and color than refinement and polish.
Name: Cueva de las Manos 2007 Reserve Malbec (Luján de Cuyo)

Description: Thick and concentrated stuff, with aromas of sweet plums and cough syrup. The body is beefy and round, with full but simple plum and blackberry flavors. With color, size and heft, it has much of what Malbec is known for. Problem is, it needs better tuning and precision to rank higher.
Name: Maipe 2007 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Heavier and more baked than desirable, with chocolate-covered berry fruit on the nose. This is a sticky, hefty wine with some balance issues. It also tastes a bit peculiar, as floral, green notes interfere with the sweet, jammy red-fruit component. A little gummy and bitter as well.
Name: Familia Marguery 2004 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Aromas of hot pepper flakes, Chinese mustard, leather and red plum are all over the map. The palate is a bit tart and tangy for Malbec, with mid-level berry flavors and a shot of tartness. Not overly ripe or happy, but with touches of quality.
Name: Alberti 154 2007 Malbec (Mendoza)

Appellation: Vin de Pays du Lot, Southwest France, France
Description: From the Cahors region of southwest France, this is a fresh, fruity, berry-flavored Malbec, a far cry from the richly tannic wines commonly produced in the region. This is a wine for fruit, for soft, open textures and for easy drinking, maybe even chilled. Screwcap.
Name: Cox 2007 Malbec (Vin de Pays du Lot)

Description: Quite stemmy and stalky, with a drawn, green edge to the bouquet. This wine tastes pickled and lean, with underdeveloped red-fruit flavors that border on vegetal but rest on green and lean. Preludio scored better several years ago; since 2003 each subsequent vintage has been weaker.
Name: Preludio 2007 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: A lean, acidic Malbec that defies the tried and true model of richness and lots of flavor. It has rhubarb and green raspberry aromas, while the palate is short, tart and herbal. Not a lot of definition here.
Name: Espuela del Gaucho 2007 Gaucho Spur Malbec (Mendoza)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This is a lovely bottle, sourced from the eastern Yakima Valley. It's a classic Washington take on Malbec, 100% varietal, with bright and crisp flavors of tart berry, hints of baking spice, plenty of acid but a pleasing softness to the tannins. The lightly leafy, herbal character of the grape shines through, making this a consummate food wine, finished at a pleasing 13.4% alcohol.
Name: Barnard Griffin 2006 Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: When people ask us, “What's your favorite value wine from Argentina,” the pet answer is this one, Pascual Toso. A former Best Buy of the year, the '07 keeps the streak of great values alive. It's round, balanced and loaded with holes-free berry and cassis aromas and flavors. It is also layered, long and composed.
Name: Pascual Toso 2007 Malbec (Maipú)

Description: A big wine, but some persistent sulphur and earthiness on the nose results in aromas of leather, scrambled eggs and tobacco. Rugged on the palate, but that's to be expected for a big-boned Malbec like this. Flavors of blackberry and black cherry are supported by powerful oak, leather and an infusion of herbs. Drinkable now and best through 2010.
Name: Tikal 2007 Amorío Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Nice and ripe, with cassis, blackberry and some oaky softness up front. The palate is convincing and properly textured, and it deals tasty cassis and plum-like flavors. Across the board this wine is comfortable and comforting; it finishes short but composed, with honest Malbec color, feel and flavor components.
Name: Bodega Aconquija 2006 Alberto Furque Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: More clean and relaxed than Chalten's 2006 Gran Reserva, this reserve-level Malbec shows generous red-fruit aromas in front of standard but totally pleasant blackberry, spice and chocolate flavors. Nicely balanced, with firm acidity, mellow but present tannins, and a medium-long, slightly oaky finish. Classic Argentine Malbec from Neuquén in Patagonia.
Name: Chaltén 2007 Reserva Malbec (Neuquén)

Description: This wine purports to cause whiplash, supposedly because it's so good, hence the “HeadSnapper” name. And while that's not likely to take place, its blackberry, toast and brambly undercurrent give it character, while the finish is cushioned and long, albeit a touch oaky. Healthy and very much worth a look, even if it won't cause your head to snap.
Name: Bodega Belgrano 2007 The HeadSnapper Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Tiza is a very good Malbec with ripe, minty, lush aromas that lead straight to juicy black plum and blackberry flavors. It's intense and powerful, but shows good balance, generosity and proper but strong oak. Expect plenty of kick, power and darkness from this wine. Drink throughout 2009 and into 2010.
Name: Tiza 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Quite toasty and black, with baked plum, berry and crusty, oaky aromas. The palate is sort of soft and lazy, but amid the thickness there's roasted plum and black cherry flavors. Finishes with some wayward buttery oak, heat and coffee notes. Chewy, ripe and a bit grabby and heavy.
Name: Belasco de Baquedano 2006 AR Guentota Old Vine Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Always a good buy and always big and husky, Gascón is a saturated and dark wine but one with good balance and texture. The nose features cola, boysenberry and density, while the palate is sweet and floral, with big berry flavors. Quite good for a fat young Malbec.
Name: Don Miguel Gascón 2007 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Quite dark and crusty on the nose, with aromas of road tar and obvious oak. Tough but real on the palate, with big tannins and lip-smacking berry and cherry flavors. Shows more oak character and resin than necessary, and thus the fruit flavors don't fully stack up to such heavy wood. Still, it gets it right more than wrong.
Name: Melipal 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Malbec is relatively new and rare in Washington, and it is still some years before most of the vines are mature, but the potential is there. This is 100% varietal, quite light, with forward fruit suggesting cherry, plum and berry. It's balanced with good acids, but there is not yet much depth or detail.
Name: Michael Florentino Cellars 2006 Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: Slightly carbonic and gassy at first, with huge candied fruit aromas. But quickly the wine settles, and out comes sweet blackberry flavors and some gumminess. It's a chunky, easy wine with medium tannins and modest plushness, which is something you shouldn't necessarily expect from a value-positioned wine. Short on the finish, but plump and buttery.
Name: Finca El Portillo 2007 Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: A heavy, blocky wine with a dark color and aromas that lean toward raisin and reduced balsamic vinegar. The palate is quite full and slightly syrupy in feel, while the flavors are of boysenberry and dark, toasty oak. Finishes with even more crusty, espresso-like wood flavors, leaving displaced wood as the lasting impression.
Name: Familia Marguery 2006 Casa Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Aromas of cherry cough drop make the bouquet slightly medicinal, but beyond that it's solid and familiar. Moderate richness on the palate accompanies flavors of butter, strawberry and raspberry. Heat, wood resin and a touch of pickle work the finish. Good wine but it doesn't exactly go the extra mile.
Name: Bodega Don Bosco 2006 Malbec (Maipú)

Description: Standard plum and berry aromas provide a nice opening to this dark, solid Malbec that's a little zingy and racy at its core. Flavors of plum and berry are typical for a wine of this class, which finishes with burnt flavors and a final resting place of grainy oak.
Name: Durigutti 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Fiery and crisp, with decent berry and cherry aromas giving it character. The palate is medium to racy, with zesty raspberry, cherry and rhubarb flavors. Finishes short and a little prickly, with heat and a hint of chocolate. Very basic, but by no means a bad wine.
Name: Tercos 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: There's more rhubarb and bramble here than we prefer from a young, everyday Malbec, and thus the bouquet is austere and only skin deep. As might be expected given the aromas, the palate is limited to herbal, lightly pickled red fruit, while the finish is quick and offers some lasting chocolate. Decent wine, but that's as far as it goes.
Name: Alta Vista 2006 Premium Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: A little cheesy and raw at first, with aromas of cement, mint and light berry fruit. The palate is sort of thin and dilute for Malbec, with an emphasis on zingy red fruit more than dense, rich black stuff. Turns jumpy and lean on the finish.
Name: Bodega Norton 2007 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Fairly herbal, with burnt briar aromas that cause it to tilt toward acrid. The palate shows mostly tart cranberry and wild berry flavors, and while it looks dark to the eye, the wine is surprisingly shallow and a little bit sharp in the end run.
Name: Altocedro 2007 Año Cero Malbec (La Consulta)

Description: Las Moras is from Argentina's La Rioja region, and Black Label aims to be its top product. But mostly the wine pushes minty, dark oak on top of superficial plum and berry fruit. It's extremely wooded, so the finish deals mint chip and raw wood flavors. A racy and sheer mouthfeel doesn't exactly help it along.
Name: Finca Las Moras 2006 Black Label Malbec (San Juan)

Description: Simple raspberry and cherry aromas carry rubbery side notes and a touch of floor polish. The palate is lean and generic, with red-fruit flavors and citrusy acidity. Modest, zesty and not much to it.
Name: Valentín Bianchi 2007 Elsa Malbec

Description: Few wineries in Argentina make more individual wines than Achaval-Ferrer. And while some are great, others leave you scratching your head or wanting something different. This one has a deep hue but a strange mix of herbal, floral aromas that hint at air freshener. The palate is quite acid-driven and downright sharp, with pounding blueberry and kirsch flavors. More austere and tangy than we prefer.
Name: Achaval-Ferrer 2007 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: The only thing that makes this a gran reserva is the label and the winery's commitment to a big, extracted, heavily oaked wine. It's black as ink but clumsy as can be. Smells and tastes like shoe polish, resin and oily fruit. Not what we're looking for from Argentina, or anywhere for that matter. Barely acceptable. Imported by Carolina Wine Brands USA.
Name: Finca El Origen 2007 Gran Reserva Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: Year by year, Salentein's top wines are improving. Primum is truly a fine wine, right up there with the country's best. It's harmonious and inviting, with cola, mineral, floral notes and honest black fruit aromas and flavors. The feel is secure and tight but also well balanced, with a touch of molasses but mostly just deep, driving black fruit. Muscular, intense and long on the finish. Drink now.
Name: Salentein 2004 Primum Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: Kaiken Ultra has emerged as a consistent top-shelf Malbec. This vintage shows power, purity, mineral, ripe fruit and well-applied oak. It's a generous wine with kirsch and raspberry parfait flavors. It almost makes it to creamy but by holding onto its core acidity it guards overall balance. Unforced but a little forceful; good for those who like a ripe, meaty red wine.
Name: Kaiken 2006 Ultra Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Part of the fun of exploring Argentine Malbec is tasting all the new kids on the block. Having not seen Guentota before, all signs point to high quality. The bouquet is dark, with accents of cola, mineral and burnt toast giving it a masculine edge. Round, plump and full in the mouth, with cherry, berry and cassis flavors. A total package of a wine, with character, nuance and serious base-level fruit.
Name: Belasco de Baquedano 2005 AR Guentota Old Vine Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Big and forward but still elegant, which is what we like. Spice and bold black fruit carry the bouquet, which leads straight to a smooth palate flush with berry, plum and cola flavors. Finishes like glass, meaning it's super smooth. A voluptuous but balanced wine, with only the slightest hint of syrup. Drink now.
Name: Ksana 2005 Reserva Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Great color, extraction and overall balance for an under-$15 wine. There's slam-bang dark fruit, good mouthfeel, tightness and serious but controlled tannins. Oak plays its role on the back palate and finish, and in the end the wine is as savory and balanced as it is bold and fruity. Drink now through 2010.
Name: Andeluna 2006 Winemaker's Selection Malbec (Tupungato)

Description: Expect a fair amount of forward, creamy oak and you'll be just fine digging into this rich, healthy Malbec (with some Cabernet Franc). Intense blackberry, black cherry and chocolate flavors bring a smile even if they don't seem that complex. But on further thought, this wine is about hedonistic richness, barrel notes and pleasure as opposed to stirring things up intellectually.
Name: Andeluna 2004 Limited Reserve Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Lush, forward and complete, with a full mix of sweet and spicy aromas leading to bright berry flavors accented by licorice and vanilla from well-managed oak. Salentein is making better wines now than ever before, and this toasty, warming number is a prized bull that can only help Argentinean Malbec preserve its good name.
Name: Salentein 2006 Reserve Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: Solid stuff, with a touch of leather and earth mingling with candied dark-fruit aromas. The wine is plush and ripe, with full black cherry and plum flavors sitting on a sturdy, medium-tannin frame. Appealing and approachable, with no glaring flaws. Excellent for near-term drinking.
Name: Kaiken 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: A true no-complaints style of wine. It shines a brilliant purple and delivers telltale vanilla and creamy aromas along with medium-depth plum, berry and oak flavors. The palate is slightly narrow but there's enough flesh, body, texture and balance for it to rank as a winner. Delivers all that a Malbec in this price range should.
Name: Bodega Norton 2006 Reserva Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Generous in aromas, with touches of berry syrup, balsam wood and spice. On first blush the wine seems a little racy and sharp, but that driving acidity also causes the cherry and plum flavors to dance rather than sit lazily on the palate. Definitely on the money, with chocolate and more on the medium-length finish.
Name: Alta Vista 2005 Grande Reserve Terroir Selection Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: After a hiatus, the Tapiz brand is back in the U.S. market. This Malbec throws off ample oak, maple and charred aromas, but the palate is sweet and ripe, with plum and berry fruit overriding any aggressive barrel characteristics. With molasses and vanilla on the finish, it's saturated, creamy and shows well as a whole.
Name: Tapiz 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: It takes a while for the wine's plum and berry aromas to rise up, but in the mouth it's a meaty Malbec with plum, berry and cassis flavors as well as a clean, precise, well-woven feel. A rock-solid wine with coffee and chocolate on the finish. Meets all expectations for a reserve-level Malbec in this price range.
Name: Andeluna 2005 Reserve Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Mint and crushed mineral aromas mix with floral scents and barrel resin to form a solid bouquet. The palate is a touch racy and sharp, and thus there's tartness to the cherry and raspberry flavors. Not sour or underdone, but definitely tilts to the red-fruit side of things.
Name: Valentín Bianchi 2006 Particular Malbec

Description: Coffee and herbs carry the nose, which leads to a mildly herbal palate of leafy berry flavors and sandalwood. This is not your ordinary Malbec comprised of big fruit and creamy oak; instead it's a mellow wine that's hardly amplified. Finishes dry, with some bitter chocolate.
Name: Finca Decero 2006 Remolinos Vineyard Malbec (Agrelo)

Description: Raspberry and cherry aromas are light and pleasing, while the palate exhibits those same friendly and inviting raspberry flavors along with some citrus. A fresh and clean wine, nothing more or less. But it manages to rise above the masses via its focus, length and purity.
Name: Melipal 2008 Rosé Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Plenty of charcoal, toast and resin work the bouquet, while the fruit seems a little candied. There's a mix of black berry notes and oak, which results in a creamy mouthfeel and lingering vanilla and sweetness. A complete Malbec, but one that's neither unique nor overly special.
Name: Chaltén 2006 Gran Reserva Malbec (Neuquén)

Description: Smoky and big on the nose, with crusty black-fruit flavors backing that up. The wine is less deep and more hard and scratchy than some Mendoza Malbecs, but it's solid and sure-footed even if the mouthfeel is stark. Probably better with food than others due to its leaner, less opulent style.
Name: Felipe Rutini 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: As a wine reviewer, I have a love-hate relationship with Achaval Ferrer's wines. I love the owners' commitment to vineyard-designated wines and harvesting early to thwart overripeness. On the other hand, wines like this seem clangy, sharp and roasted on the nose, while richness and depth of flavor seem to be lacking. The end result is a hollow wine that works best on the surfaces.
Name: Achaval-Ferrer 2006 Finca Mirador Malbec (Medrano)

Description: Berry fruit with a charcoal accent make for perfectly adequate starting aromas. The palate, however, is more tangy and sharp-edged than you might expect, and thus there's driving red-fruit flavors but not much cushion or variance. Solid enough but a touch choppy on the finish. Most leading Malbecs have a bit more stuffing than this one, which seems tight.
Name: Ksana 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Something about this high-end Malbec is strange. And in this case, “strange” doesn't mean bad, it just means very different and a little distracting. Right off the bat there's an herbal/exotic edge to the nose, and that translates onto the palate. Is it body oil or crushed flowers or what? Something is unusual, and in the end the tried and true might be preferable. 250 cases produced.
Name: Ksana 2004 Gran Reserva Single Vineyard Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Light and fruity, with some gallop in its stride. On the minus side, it smells sort of sweet and confected, like cotton candy. In the mouth, it's varietally neutral. Thus flavors of apricot and nectarine more than berry or cherry are what you get. Flashy in its current youthful state; drink soon before it loses focus.
Name: Finca El Portillo 2008 Rosé Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: Seems more bretty, gaseous and muddled than it should be. The nose is burnt and rustic, and to an extent so is the palate. Mouthfeel   is quite good, and that's a saving grace because overall there's an earthy, leathery thing going on that doesn't really mesh with the Argentine model of clean bold fruit, oak and not much else.
Name: Preludio 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Innocuous aromas lead to a palate of sweet, semi-candied strawberry and plum flavors. The wine is almost creamy in the mouth, which for dry rosé seems a bit thick. Acceptable in every way, but doesn't rise above average. Drink before it loses steam.
Name: Pascual Toso 2008 Rosé Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: More stemmy and cooked-smelling than ideal. This wine seems to have lost about half of its freshness, leaving earthy, semi-burnt nectarine and orange flavors. As the 2008s come out, this oldie just isn't forward and clean enough to stir excitement.
Name: Finca la Celia 2007 Eagle's Rock Rosé Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Since 2000, this top cuvée made by Pascal Verhaeghe, shows the results of Verhaeghe's experience in Burgundy and in California at Saintsbury winery in Napa. Its barrel aging creates a smooth texture, allowing the Malbec to express itself in huge black fruits and strong mint char-acter. It needs aging even after six years—give it another four at least.
Name: Château du Cèdre 2002 GC Malbec (Cahors)

Description: In the Middle Ages, the wines of Cahors used to be called “black wines” and the tradition comes from cooking the grapes for a night after harvest. Jean-Luc Baldès has revived the tradition in this limited production wine, with its glass-staining deep crimson color. The palate is dominated by prunes, dried raisins and a series of impressive perfumes that go through the dense, definitely black, tannins. Age for 10 years before even touching.
Name: Clos Triguedina 2005 The Black Wine Malbec (Cahors)

Description: From a selection of different parcels on the estate of Château du Cèdre, here is a wine that broods in the glass. It's just beginning to give out its dark fruits, very black and jammy, along with serious amounts of wood, tight spice and menthol. Powerful, impressive.
Name: Château du Cèdre 2002 Le Cèdre Malbec (Cahors)

Description: This is Alain Dominique Perrin's answer to the black wine of Cahors. Hugely dark in color, this micro cuvée is still impenetrable after eight years. The power and the density edge towards the medicinal, with a very herbal element in the flavors alongside the wood, black-plum skins and spice.
Name: Château Lagrézette 2000 Le Pigeonnier Malbec (Cahors)

Description: Just a small proportion of Merlot smoothes out the hard Malbec edges in this impressive cuvée from Château Lagrezette. It is certainly powerful, the wood prominent but not too dominant. With advice from Michel Rolland, this shows great polish without losing entirely that mineral, dark edge. Age for 5–6 years.
Name: Château Lagrézette 2003 Cuvée Dame d'Honneur Malbec (Cahors)

Description: Named after the Roman emperor who introduced vines to Cahors in the 3rd century, this 100% Malbec from old vines is a wonderfully rich wine, dark in color and dominated by dense, smoky tannins. There is wood there, a subtle underlay to all the black, ripe fruits. It should be aged for five years at least.
Name: Clos Triguedina 2005 Probus Malbec (Cahors)

Description: A very perfumed, minty wine, promising spicy new wood flavors. These come through strongly, but not to the detriment of the delicious, full, smooth black-fruit flavors. The wine is certainly sweet, with soft toast and ripe tannins, finishing with some vibrant acidity.
Name: Château la Reyne 2005 L'Excellence Malbec (Cahors)

Description: A fruit lover's wine. Broad black cherry and leather aromas set up a smooth but hefty palate with deep berry flavors, spice and smoked meat. Rich but balanced, with a heaping of heavenly chocolate on the finish. A firm and structured wine with fine depth and distance.
Name: Monteviejo 2004 Lindaflor Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: A wine that is in such good balance that no one element stands out. They are all melded into a rich wine, dry, but with delicious juiciness as well as acidity. The flavors show the quality of the black fruits, but also how the tannins are a fine support, along with spice from the wood. Age for 4–5 years.
Name: Château Lamartine 2005 Cuvée Particulière Malbec (Cahors)

Description: The balancing of bright, vibrant berry fruit with charcoal and chocolate give this a very pleasant but manly outlook. Medium in texture, with firm but flexible tannins backing up strapping blackberry and cassis flavors. Coffee and mocha are draped all over the big, long finish. It's yet another rock-solid wine from the Clos 7 project.
Name: Cuvelier los Andes 2005 Grand Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: You want power from Malbec? This is it, a solid, dense, structured wine, whose wood element gives vanilla and spice. The fruit meanwhile needs time, its richness under the wood, but it is certainly there. There is weight but that Malbec acidity just powers through to add freshness.
Name: Le Clos d'un Jour 2005 Un Jour…. Malbec (Cahors)

Description: Top-notch Malbec blended with other varieties gives Corte A a chance at greatness. In its current juvenile state, the wine is fresh, expressive and exotic on the nose, with mineral, licorice and spice in addition to a lot of driving berry character. The core is a touch racy and acidic, so this is no mushy fruit bomb. Instead it is serious wine with a lot of oak, polish and pizzazz.
Name: Vistalba 2006 Corte A Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Our favorite of the Trapiche 2005 single-vineyard Malbecs is this one from Fausto Orellana. Winemaker Daniel Pi has made a brawny but savory wine with structure, core acidity and bold flavors. The palate is chunky and expansive, but also smooth and well directed. Some unabsorbed oak, tannins and more indicate that this bruiser is here to stay. Best from 2009 through 2014.
Name: Trapiche 2005 Viña Fausto Orellana Single Vineyard Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: As per usual, this Patagonian beauty ranks high on our scale of classy Malbecs. It's well-oaked, which results in hickory and campfire aromas alongside dark berries and mineral. The palate is ripe and meaty, with blackberry and coffee flavors. Some vanilla and coconut on the finish is a reminder of the fine oak treatment this wine receives. Fine acidity and tannic structure only help it to achieve its goal.
Name: Bodega Noemía de Patagonia 2006 Noemía Malbec (Río Negro Valley)

Description: Dominated by Malbec, but with some Tannat and Merlot in the blend, this chateau wine is dark and dense, with a piercing layer of acidity. There is a strong mineral character here, stony and firm, but without extreme weight. The tannins come through to give a very dry core.
Name: Château du Cèdre 2004 Le Prestige Malbec (Cahors)

Description: Big, dark and masculine, with shoe polish, coconut, cola and burnt toast aromas accenting intense plum and blackberry. All of Trapiche's single-vineyard signature wines have been excellent in recent years, and this one from Francisco Olivé's vineyard is robust and shows all the requisite and familiar dark berry, cassis and barrel characteristics. A huge, modern, steak-friendly red to drink now through 2012.
Name: Trapiche 2005 Viña Francisco Olivé Single Vineyard Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: This is wonderfully rich and dense, with dry and dusty tannins that float in the depths of the powerful black fruits, well integrated with the wood. This is impressive Malbec, showing its juicy qualities allied with its huge tannins. It could do with 3–4 years' aging.
Name: Clos Troteligotte 2005 K Lys Malbec (Cahors)

Description: Ripe, generous, mint-and eucalypt-flavored wine, shot through with dry tannins and minerality, but also showing fine blackberry and dark plum-skin flavors. There is a satisfying tension here between fruit and herbal characters, promising good aging—try it again in five years.
Name: Château de Gaudou 2005 Réserve de Caillau Malbec (Cahors)

Description: This is the top wine from Château Haute-Serre, a powerful expression of Malbec, very dense and solid, but certainly not overpowering. It has ripe fruit that is held in check by brooding tannins and a firm structure, giving it weight but also surprising restraint. Age for 4–5 years.
Designation: Château de Haute-Serre Cuvée Géron Dadine
Name: Georges Vigouroux 2005 Château de Haute-Serre Cuvée Géron Dadine Malbec (Cahors)

Description: Three years ago Trapiche started making three high-end single-vineyard Malbecs; Aciar's seems a little more closed and flat than its cousins, but it does pump forward with rock-solid blackberry and cola flavors. It's better on the attack than the follow-through, but the flavors are excellent and the balance is proper even if the length is short.
Name: Trapiche 2005 Viña Eleodoro Aciar Single Vineyard Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: The tiny, 17-acre vineyard of Le Clos d'un Jour produces three wines; this is the middle in quality terms. It was aged in earthenware jars, reproducing ancient techniques. The wine, despite its dark color, is light, refreshing, a model of delicious black fruits and vivid acidity. The tannins are tight and spicy with a bitter-chocolate edge.
Name: Le Clos d'un Jour 2006 Un Jour sur Terre Malbec (Cahors)

Appellation: Altos de Mendoza, Mendoza Province, Argentina
Description: Roasted and a touch fiery at first, but then this big-boned Malbec settles into a dark-fruit zone with accents of fresh herbs and tobacco. It's a structured wine with nice plum, blackberry and chocolate flavors, while licorice and herbal notes work the finish. The last vintage of Armorío we tried was 2001; so it's good to see the wine is holding steady.
Name: Tikal 2006 Amorío Malbec (Altos de Mendoza)

Description: The curious name refers to the density of the vines per hectare (2,700 per acre), giving the vines stress and therefore smaller yields per plant. The result is a tough, concentrated wine, powered by tannins, new wood and very structured fruit. Give it 10 years.
Name: Georges Vigouroux 2005 Château Mercuès Cuvée 6666 Malbec (Cahors)

Description: Négociant Xavier Copel, although based in Bordeaux, makes and bottles his Cahors in the region of production. This is the top of his Cahors range, a broad-brush wine, with rich, almost sweet fruit, acidity and layers of equally sweet wood. It's big, but it works.
Name: Primo Palatum 2002 Mythologia Malbec (Cahors)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This Malbec was finished in Hungarian oak, about one-third new, and it's 100% varietal. The aromas are a luscious mix of passion- fruit and blueberry, and the flavors are blueberry all the way. The tannins are soft and set the fruit up gracefully; it rolls over the tongue and explodes on the palate sensuously, adding spice and chocolate as it gently fades.
Name: Seven Hills 2006 Malbec (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Description: It's wood all the way with this wine. From the initial aromas to the sweet, juicy wood-dominated fruit, there is spice and high toast. And yet the fruit is big enough to stay in there, hugely rich brooding power and density. Age for 2–3 years, but not more.
Name: Château la Caminade 2004 Esprit Malbec (Cahors)

Description: “The breath of an angel” is the best translation of the name. The wine is more earthbound, but still has considerable elegance, the texture very fine, layering spice, acidity and flavors of licorice, mineral and ripe berries. With its smoothness, it is almost ready to drink—try it this winter.
Name: Château la Reyne 2005 Vent d'Ange Malbec (Cahors)

Description: The strange set of initials for Charte de Qualité, Fûts de Chêne (wood barrels). Emmanuel Rybinski worked in Australia and California, and this shows in the dominant use of wood. It cuts through the already rich Malbec fruit with its great juicy, black richness. With that weight of fruit, it should be worth waiting for the wood to calm down.
Name: Clos Troteligotte 2005 CQfd Malbec (Cahors)

Description: Properly black in color, this exudes spice, wood and rich, delicious fruit. The elements are already working in balance, giving plenty of solid but dusty tannins on top of the black-plum and bitter-chocolate flavors. Age this wine for 4–5 years, but it will be delicious next year.
Name: Château la Caminade 2005 La Commandery Malbec (Cahors)

Description: A smooth, voluptuous interpretation of Malbec, this shows bitter chocolate and licorice flavors as well as dense, mineral black fruits. The Malbec juiciness is evident, while the wood acts as a rounded support. Big, rich, and balanced.
Name: Château Lagrézette 2003 Cru d'Exception Malbec (Cahors)

Description: Ripe, bold and creamy, with vanilla and plum aromas. Vivid on the palate, with cherry, blackberry, coffee and chocolate flavors all registering. It's almost a lush wine, but there's firm but controlled acidity and tannins that keep it from losing focus. A Malbec that rises and conquers, and the price is right.
Name: Mapema 2005 Malbec (Mendoza)

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This is 100% Malbec from the Wahluke Slope AVA, and it is delicious. It has the sharp tannins and spicy herbaceousness of the grape, with very tight, tart cassis and black raspberry fruit. Firm, tight, pure and clean, it's an excellent example of the variety.
Name: William Church 2006 Malbec (Wahluke Slope)

Description: The style from La Reyne is becoming more refined, more structured as the vineyard matures. This 2006 is dense, black in color, with prominent wood elements, but still keeping fruit freshness, a delicious layer of black currants and spice, touched with licorice.
Name: Château la Reyne 2006 Le Prestige Malbec (Cahors)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The Malbec—firm and muscular—is amplified with 23% Cabernet Sauvignon from the estimable Bacchus vineyard. The wine is dark, what some call brooding, with tight, spicy boysenberry fruit, wrapped in smoky tannins. It seems to be holding something in reserve, for it tails off after an auspicious beginning once it hits the mid-palate. Tannins are well-managed but astringent; this wine needs a few more years in the cellar to show its best.
Name: Three Rivers 2006 Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: Tight and compact at first, then it shows a lot of rustic leather, herbs and olive along with plum, berry and ample oak. This is a charged wine, and its power is omnipresent even if it shows only moderate depth and structure. Finishes toasty, with mocha and cappuccino aftertastes.
Name: Tiza 2005 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: A little reduced on the nose, so it opens with licorice and some gassy, rubbery qualities. Time sends it in a good direction; what's left is big, meaty fruit flavors with mild tannins and good overall balance. Full and chewy right now, so drink sooner rather than later. Best now through spring 2009.
Name: La Posta 2006 Pizzella Family Vineyard Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: A rich, dense wine, packed with ripe flavors of black fruits, along with perfume from wood maturation. It has power, concentration and a potential for several years' aging.
Name: Château de Gaudou 2005 Cuvée Tradition Malbec (Cahors)

Description: The basic Cahors from Clos d'un Jour is a fine revelation, brimming with blackberry fruits, dense tannins and ripe acidity. It revels in its dark colors and its freshness. Drink now.
Name: Le Clos d'un Jour 2004 Malbec (Cahors)

Description: Comes out firing, with hints of thistle, leather and campfire accenting blueberry and blackberry aromas. The palate keeps that same mix of herbs and black fruit, while the feel is rich to the point of suggesting berry syrup. With mocha, molasses and coffee on the finish, this is a big Malbec for near-term drinking.
Name: BenMarco 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: A deep-berried wine with penetrating fruit character and very smooth tannins. In fact, this is such a smooth wine that it almost registers as thick and syrupy. But down deep, at its very core, there's just enough pulse to make it vital. Still, there's no denying the blackberry, dark plum and raisiny richness on this Patagonian Malbec. Drink now through 2009.
Name: Bodega Noemía de Patagonia 2007 J. Alberto Malbec (Río Negro Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Just the second Malbec from Fidélitas, this pure varietal bottling opens with deep, dark aromas of smoke, coffee and pepper, with saturated colors that seem to promise a dense, exotic wine. Though it is lively and offers nice flavors of pepper, berry and spice, it does not have the concentration in the mouth that the aromas suggest. There are some prickly herbal flavors, along with light chocolate, in the finish.
Name: Fidelitas 2005 Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: This critter wine hasn't been consistent, but this vintage is very good. The nose is dry and a little bit woody, while the palate has roasted, fully ripe fruit backed by woodspice and chewy tannins. Some herbal character works its way into play, but overall this is recommended everyday Malbec.
Name: Ñandú 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: The original “black wine” of Cahors is obviously alive and well—and living in the Loire valley, to judge by the color of this wine. Made from ungrafted Malbec, this is rich, unoaked, a ripe but stalky textured wine that gives great perfumes and a firm, juicy and tannic aftertaste.
Name: Henry Marionnet 2007 Vinifera Malbec (Touraine)

Description: High Note reaches the high notes, the middle notes and the bass notes. It starts with dark berry aromas and clarity, while the palate is lively and fresh, with cherry and a light undercurrent of olive for flavors. A full, honest Malbec with size, character and balance.
Name: High Note 2007 Elevated Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: Fresh, juicy black berry fruits and a dominant layer of acidity cover the wood spice and toast in this wine. It is fruity more than hugely structured, despite its dry tannins. The acidity continues right through, leaving a vivid, mouthwatering aftertaste.
Name: Clos Troteligotte 2005 K Price Malbec (Cahors)

Description: Good red fruit on the opening and spicy. Ripe, intense and warming in the mouth, with a broad-sweeping wave of plum and raspberry. Feels a little creamy and then drying on the finish, with medium depth and lasting heat. Due to high alcohol and a related burn it needs food, i.e. anything off the grill.
Name: Tomero 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Rubber and savory berry aromas lead it off. The palate shows good texture and overall smoothness, with round cassis and plum flavors. Very competent and solid on the finish, with toasty, warming afternotes and only a slight tannic grab. Textbook Malbec given the price range.
Name: Andes Grapes 2006 Ambar 1907 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Ripe, full, sweet, oaky and even a touch confectionary, with a whiff of cotton candy blending with resin and spice from the barrels. The palate is superconcentrated, with blackberry and chocolate flavors, and on the finish the oak pushes things toward toast, coconut and burnt logs. Woody, but powerful and appealing.
Name: Finca Sophenia 2007 Synthesis Malbec (Tupungato)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Dark, smoky and herbal, this wine, the second Malbec from Maryhill, does capture some of that grape's lovely character. Tart wild berry fruit is cut with sharp acids, and laced with herb and hints of stone. There is a bit of saddle leather showing through the tannins, but not so much as to wipe out the sweet fruit. A persistent finish tastes like fresh picked raspberries.
Name: Maryhill 2005 Proprietor's Reserve Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: A wine that shows the more friendly, less powerful side of Malbec. A ripe, fruity wine, dominated by its black currant flavors, the juiciness running through the tight, mineral character.
Name: Clos Troteligotte 2004 La Fourmi Malbec (Cahors)

Description: This least-expensive estate wine from La Caminade is also the fruitiest, an explosion of black berries and freshness, layered with cranberry dryness. The wine is delicious, ready to drink, pure fruit.
Name: Château la Caminade 2005 Malbec (Cahors)

Description: A ripe, attractively fruity wine that shows the drink-me side of Malbec without losing the intense structure and dark tannins that also characterize the grape. It is big and bold, but also accessible now.
Name: Château Lagrézette 2003 Zette Rouge Malbec (Cahors)

Description: A wine that emphasizes its minerality, the tannins almost stony in character. Big ripe blackberry jam flavors roll around the glass, but it remains a dry wine, with a risk that the texture will get too fat.
Name: Primo Palatum 2003 Classica Malbec (Cahors)

Description: Slightly closed and murky at first, but with airing it comes to life. The palate is tight and lively due to full acidity, but it gives structure and purpose to the wine's berry and pepper flavors. A little fiery but also endowed with length. Contains 13% Cabernet Sauvignon and Tempranillo.
Name: Ruca Malen 2004 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Soft, rich and full-bodied, but still well balanced and not flabby. If that sounds like good Malbec, then you're going to be happy with this dark, easygoing chunkster. Slightly bitter on the finish, but like coffee more than anything unpleasant.
Name: Andean Sky 2007 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: This is the basic wine from Château du Cèdre, but it shows already the quality of wines produced at this leading Cahors estate. Ripe blackberry fruits, tightened with acidity, co-star with a delicious burst of spice and dry tannins.
Name: Château du Cèdre 2005 Héritage Malbec (Cahors)

Description: This is a traditional style—emphasizing earthy tannins and spicy fruit and is rough around the edges—but is a wine that would relish being partnered with sausages, salamis and hard cheeses. There is plenty of weight, the acidity coming from minerality and wood.
Name: Clos de Gamot 2002 Cuvée des Vignes Centenaires Malbec (Cahors)

Appellation: Vin de Pays du Comté Tolosan, Southwest France, France
Description: A wine that is all about fruit. The flavors are of licorice, with some bitter herbs, but there's also black currant jelly to go along with the fresh and vibrant acidity.
Name: Clos Triguedina 2005 Le Malbec du Clos Malbec (Vin de Pays du Comté Tolosan)
Region: Vin de Pays du Comté Tolosan

Description: Rubbery and smoky at first, with leather and berry fruit running secondary to the wine's more reduced qualities. But if given ten minutes to unwind, it shows wide black-fruit flavors, creaminess and finally some barrel-based resin. Gets better the more you work with it, but will always register as “oaky.”
Name: Melipal 2006 Reserve Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Seems like the most extracted, borderline raisiny A-Lisa to date (it began with the 2005 vintage). But if a touch of overripeness isn't a turn-off, then this meaty Malbec from Patagonia will be appealing for its plum, berry and chocolate talking points. Because it's so full and luggish, we say drink it soon.
Name: Bodega Noemía de Patagonia 2007 A-Lisa Malbec (Río Negro Valley)

Description: There's good dense fruit here, with a blackberry jam quality to the ripe fruit. The wine misses some richness, but makes up for it with its lively smooth tannins and acidity, and ripe, juicy aftertaste.
Name: Clos de Gamot 2005 Malbec (Cahors)

Description: Blueberry, citrus peel and licorice work the nose on this interesting but limited Malbec. The palate seems racier and more acidic than one might expect, with snappy black cherry and berry flavors. Oak rises up on the finish, leaving chocolate in spades. Has critical mass but only medium depth and complexity.
Name: Caliterra 2006 Tribute Malbec (Colchagua Valley)

Description: Cloudy and a little stewy at first, which gives it a richer, plumper outward personality. With loads of earth and leather, fruit takes an early back seat before rising up in the form of black plum and berry. Finishes plump, with adequate structure. Gets better the more you get to know it.
Name: La Posta 2006 Angel Paulucci Vineyard Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Jammy aromas of raspberry and cherry show a slightly pickled, brambly edge, while the palate delivers tight, grabby cherry and berry flavors. There's a bit of cheesy tang to the finish, while sheering acidity and an overall light body make it food friendly.
Name: Terrazas de Los Andes 2006 Reserva Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Dark and quite oaky for a brand that earned its stripes via balanced wines that overdelivered. This vintage seems much more extracted and rough, with big, burly aromas and then tannins that grab the cheeks. Along the rough and tumble ride there's spice, pepper, blackberry and coffee. This wine pumps it out but is less polished than in the past.
Name: Susana Balbo 2007 Crios Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: A fresh, earthy wine that edges towards rustic, bringing with it some firm, very dry tannins as well as a dense, black fruit and plum skin structure. It's not a wine for aging, but demands solid winter food to be at its best.
Name: Clos Troteligotte 2005 La Perdrix Malbec (Cahors)

Appellation: Vin de Pays du Lot, Southwest France, France
Description: Fresh acidity and a dry style make this a great food rosé. It has crisp red berry and currant fruits,  vibrant acidity and a lively aftertaste.
Name: Clos Troteligotte 2007 Rosé Troteligotte Malbec (Vin de Pays du Lot)

Description: Floral and clean on the nose, with good red fruit and cherry flavors. By no means is this a fat-styled, extracted Malbec. Instead it's fresh and crisp, but tasty and pretty well balanced, especially if there's some food along for the ride. Imported by USA Wine Imports.
Name: Finca Los Maza 2005 Colección Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Reduced and rubbery at first, but airing reveals bouncy cherry and raspberry aromas and flavors. The feel is juicy, almost whispy thin, and the finish is clean yet racy. If you don't mind a thinner palate that still carries good fruit (think Sangiovese), this is in that style.
Name: Finca El Retiro 2005 Reserva Especial Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: This may be the first time this wine has been labeled Reserve; in the past it was just Finca Sophenia Malbec. And truth be told, it's a good but regular Malbec with berries and raisin on the bouquet, and then juicy berry fruit on the palate. Solidly made, with solid structure.
Name: Finca Sophenia 2007 Reserve Malbec (Tupungato)

Description: From old vines, this wine is certainly concentrated and powerful. But with an edge of bitterness, there is also the sense that the wine is too extracted, too intent on showing up its darkness, its dense structure and its impressive tannins.
Name: Château Haut-Monplaisir 2003 Pur Plaisir Malbec Malbec (Cahors)

Description: Firm, tough, mineral and austere, this is a dense wine that grabs you with its structure and dark fruits. The acidity is lean, needing more time to develop as the wine fleshes out.
Name: Georges Vigouroux 2005 Pigmentum Malbec (Cahors)

Appellation: Altos de Mendoza, Mendoza Province, Argentina
Description: Fairly reduced, leaving gaseous aromas to struggle with earthy fruit. Talk about chunky ripe fruit and soft tannins: this has almost no detectable grip or grab, thus the structure is flabby and there's zero bite. Conversely, the flavors are deep and the richness is up there. Drink now.
Name: Luca 2006 Malbec (Altos de Mendoza)

Description: Toso's first-ever rosé of Malbec comes in a salmon color, with clean but generic aromas of melon, cotton candy and wet stones. The palate deals sweet peach with some spice, and the mouthfeel is full. Good in a round, drink-me-soon style.
Name: Pascual Toso 2007 Rosé Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Dry and short on fruit, with strong barrel aromas of pepper, cinnamon and resin. In the mouth, there's more wood than fruit, leaving heat, vanilla and spice to overshadow mild strawberry/raspberry flavors. What's best about the wine is the mouthfeel; it's round and creamy, with length. Anyone averse to forward oak should steer clear of Utopía.
Name: Viña El Cerno 2006 Utopía Roble Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Melted fudge and asphalt are draped on this young wine's bouquet. Given that opening, a palate of black plum and cassis isn't surprising. Feelwise, it's a touch rough and tannic, which is probably to be expected. Turns more herbal the more you sniff and swirl.
Name: Finca El Retiro 2006 Barrica Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Creamy and rooty at first, and then smokier and darker as it settles. For young Malbec it displays both a jammy fruit side and an acidic center. So there's both ripeness and heft but also a piercing sizzle. Perfectly good for parties and less-serious imbibing.
Name: Budini 2007 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: More sweet and rooty than precise on the nose, with spice, leather and oak playing backup. The palate is short in fruit and depth, with mild sharpness and tang to the raspberry and plum flavors. Blends kick and jangled edges with plenty of oak and lactic notes, and in the end it's good but not up to prime time.
Name: Altocedro 2006 Reserva Malbec (La Consulta)

Description: A bit of dust and leather for openers, with short black-fruit flavors and a big wave of tannins on the palate. So expect some grab and choppiness. Despite moderate hardness, there's good dark fruit and limited herbal intrusion.
Name: Finca Sophenia 2007 Altosur Malbec (Tupungato)

Description: Obvio means obvious in Spanish, and this is an obvious yet fairly good Malbec. There's some ground spice, cinnamon and a little bretty cheese to the nose, but the palate is solid, and the berry and cherry flavors are correct for the variety. Best by the glass or in casual settings.
Name: Obvio 2007 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Wood-aged Malbec, and yes, the wood is all there. There is some fruit, red berries and some sweetness, but the wood dominates at this stage. Give it two years. Very provisional as of now.
Name: Château de Gaudou 2004 Renaissance Malbec (Cahors)

Description: From Santa Carolina, this Malbec is what you'd call meaty but a little raisiny. It shows signs of mild reduction, which pushes the flavors to marmalade. Pepper and a little coffee-like bitterness on the finish close the show. Drink now. Imported by Carolina Wine Brands USA.
Name: Finca El Origen 2007 Reserva Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: Mildly lactic on the nose, with rhubarb and some leafiness. Gets better with airing as it offers chunky, rubbery black fruit and licorice flavors. Finishes thick and chewy, with grabby tannins. Not the most exciting, lively wine going but decent enough.
Name: Xama Kaye 2004 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Sharp and sassy for the most part, but with airing things improve a bit and you start to find red fruit and honest spice. The feel is lean and vibrant, with jumpy acids creating a crisp mouthfeel. Will settle somewhat but won't ever deliver much in the way of rich berry fruit or a chewy mouthfeel.
Name: Terrazas de Los Andes 2007 Malbec (Mendoza)

Appellation: Vin de Pays du Lot, Southwest France, France
Description: A simple, unoaked Malbec that shows the earthy character, black fruit and high acidity of the grape. It's a straightforward wine, its acidity masking ripe fruits and a layer of dry tannin.
Name: Château la Caminade 2006 Malbec (Vin de Pays du Lot)

Description: Quite raisiny and pruny, from nose to palate to finish. But along the way there are touches of chocolate, earth, leather and cassis that help keep it afloat. And while we'd say it's probably too old and flat to warrant much of your time, it does have just enough pulse to still be alive. Imported by Vinecrest Co.
Name: Domaine Don Gonzalo 2001 Private Reserve Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Rubber, mushroom and smoke rise up on the hot, molten nose, while the palate is hard, tough to penetrate and narrow, with dark berry and piercing pepper accents. Tough to dig into and find higher qualities. Thus it comes across as a surface wine without much depth or elegance.
Name: San Polo 2006 Auka Malbec (La Consulta)

Description: Almost red in color, and maybe already past its prime. Crios was a standout in 2006, but the '07 is chunky and sweet smelling, with ripe but dull apple, melon and nectarine flavors. Soft and already in its late stages; probably best to wait for the 2008.
Name: Susana Balbo 2007 Crios Rosé of Malbec (Mendoza)

Appellation: Vin de Pays du Lot, Southwest France, France
Description: Fresh strawberry flavors, followed by some vanilla and sweet acidity characterize this wine from the Lagrezette winery. With its blend of Malbec, Syrah and white Viognier, this has softness, ripeness and, despite its acidity, a definite sweet finish.
Name: Château Lagrézette 2007 Zette Rosé Malbec (Vin de Pays du Lot)

Description: This is swinging and missing more than it's making contact. The wine is dark and broad for sure, but it's way more flat and creamy than lively, with jammy fruit that falls apart on the back palate and finish. Too bland and unstructured for how young it is.
Name: Viejo Isaias 2006 Reserve Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Super young and underdeveloped, so you get unripe pickled aromas and then racy, acid-driven flavors of grapefruit and rhubarb. Starts more promising than it finishes; the more you get to know it, the less ripe and friendly it becomes.
Name: Finca Sophenia 2008 Altosur Rosé Malbec (Tupungato)

Description: Barrel city, with piercing, dark aromas on a fleshy, flabby frame. Normally we are big fans of Susana Balbo's wines, but this Malbec is sweet, syrupy and sticky, with prune and jam-like flavors and hardly any spine. Can you say overripe and overoaked?
Name: Susana Balbo 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Smells like a field of wild flowers and weeds on a hot summer's day. There's sweaty leather and rhubarb along with murky, mildly soupy berry flavors. Lacks proper balance and freshness, and instead shows a weedy, sticky side.
Name: Santa Ana 2006 Reserve Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Hard and fiery, with spearmint dominating the nose. Raw and jumpy in the mouth, with hard berry and coffee flavors. Not much else to say about this tough wine; it's a fighter not a lover. Imported by USA Wine Imports.
Name: Finca Los Maza 2006 Don Maza Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Raw, rubbery and just not that good of a wine. Bramble, leather and compost muscle out any fruit aromas, and on the palate it's perky to the point of being acidic. Lacks balance while burning up everything in its path.
Name: Bressia 2005 Monteagrelo Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Brambly aromas precede sour flavors of pie cherry and green strawberry. A sheering wine that's miserly even by Funky Llama's standards. The best that can be said about this tart Malbec is that it isn't overripe or sappy.
Name: Funky Llama 2007 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: One of Chile's best Malbecs. This vintage is very rich and compact, with blackberry, marzipan and cola aromas. The palate is firm and sturdy, but more like a bench than a plush chair. Superripe and a little clumsy, with really intense cassis and cherry flavors. Fruity almost to the point of being over the top.
Name: Odfjell 2005 Orzada Malbec (Lontué Valley)

Description: The aromas get earthy and murky pretty quickly, but the palate mixes in enough blackberry and baked plum to offset the olive and herbal flavors that are also in play. There's plenty of tannic weight and body.
Name: Botalcura 2006 La Porfia Grand Reserve Malbec (Maipo Valley)

Description: Smells like young, gangly wine. Bubble gum and Kool-Aid aromas get only more grapy, while the palate is jumpy and aggressive. Lots of wild berry flavor, earth, herbal overtones and heat. Devoid of any sophistication.
Name: Valdivieso 2007 Malbec (Central Valley)

Description: Heavy as dead weight, with a raisiny nose. Only dried out, semisalty plum flavors work the palate.
Name: Luis Felipe Edwards 2006 Family Selection Malbec (Colchagua Valley)

Description: Talk about a deep, luscious wine. The bouquet emits a magnetic blend of chocolate cake, fine leather and berry marmalade, while the midsection is downright delicious but also very pure and natural despite the wine seeing 20 months of new oak. ACrux catches and holds every note, and it should age well for another 5 to 8 years.
Name: O. Fournier 2004 Alfa Crux Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: Argentino is a Malbec made from two vineyards: Adrianna in Tupungato and Nicasia in Vista Flores/Altamira. Aged for two years in new oak, it's a dark, vibrant masculine wine with excellent depth of flavor, seductive berry flavors, and lots of length. It hits with force but also finesse, and it shows the extracted richness that comes from small-lot open bin fermentation.
Name: Bodega Catena Zapata 2004 Argentino Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: A big, floral, fruity wine with all the hallmarks of excellence. The fruit is exacting, ripe and healthy, the tannins are firm, and the acidity is just right. It avoids all pitfalls as it transitions well from nose to palate to finish. Lots of fruit to ponder, then coffee, spice and chocolate at the end.
Name: J. & F. Lurton 2004 Chacayes Malbec (Uco Valley)

Appellation: Luján de Cuyo, Mendoza Province, Argentina
Description: Sweet, ripe, smooth and serious: this is top-shelf Malbec the way it should be. The bouquet is deep and brawny, with very ripe but balanced berry and toast aromas. Plum, blackberry and chocolate flavors are expansive and head straight to a fine finish that's lengthy and rock solid. Best now into 2010.
Name: Monte Cinco 2005 Oak Malbec (Luján de Cuyo)

Description: Adrianna sits at 5,000 feet, making it one of the highest vineyards in all of Mendoza. The wine shows pure Tupungato mountain fruit, with deep chocolaty undertones and lots of fine, toasty French oak. For deep berry flavors and smoothness more than rough and tough, Adrianna is on the money. Drink now through 2011.
Name: Bodega Catena Zapata 2004 Catena Adrianna Vineyard Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: A studly Malbec sourced from the Altamira section of the Uco Valley, then aged 18 months in new French oak. Much of this wine is fermented in plastic bins (not tanks), and the affiliated intensity grabs your attention. The blackberry flavors are potent and backed by heavy chocolate and toast. Lots of mouthfeel and power, with tannic grab. This wine can age several more years.
Name: Bodega Catena Zapata 2004 Catena Nicasia Vineyard Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: Big-format Malbec is what we're calling this new 15.5% wine from Benjamin de Rothschild and Laurent Dassault, original partners in Michel Rolland's Clos de los Siete project. Round, lush and full of body, Flechas shows muscle but little fat. It's colorful, dark, full of black fruit and long on the finish. It is modern Malbec done for modern palates.
Name: Flechas de los Andes 2006 Gran Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: One of the most untouched, terroir-driven Malbecs made in Argentina is Achaval-Ferrer's Altamira. It's harvested about three weeks earlier than most high-end fruit, resulting in core raspberry flavors and a certain redness of character. The wine is unfined and cloudy but still very clear on the palate, with length, power and class. Best from 2009–2012.
Name: Achaval-Ferrer 2006 Finca Altamira Malbec (La Consulta)

Description: This dark, meaty Malbec has some Agrelo fruit in it but it's mostly from La Consulta and Vista Flores in the Uco Valley. Aged in new oak for 18 months, it smells rich, smooth and inviting, with asphalt, mineral, violet and coffee aromas. The palate has bold acidity and healthy flavors that settle on blackberry and dark chocolate. Drink now through 2011.
Name: J. & F. Lurton 2004 Piedra Negra Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: There is a select group of under-$20 Malbecs from Argentina that really do the country and the variety proud. Santos is one of them; the 2006 is easy and ripe on the nose, with lovely cola, berry and herb aromas. The palate has a natural feel and bright black-fruit flavors. Not overly complex but a winner for the next year or two.
Name: Ricardo Santos 2006 La Madras Vineyard Malbec (Mendoza)

Appellation: Luján de Cuyo, Mendoza Province, Argentina
Description: Compared to the regular 2006 Malbec from Chakana, this wine steps up in weight class and wins the crown. It's a serious but inviting red with spongey, ripe berry aromas topped by pure raspberry, cherry and cola flavors. It's both racy and composed, with a pile of bitter chocolate on the long finish. Good through 2009 at least.
Name: Chakana 2006 Reserve Malbec (Luján de Cuyo)

Appellation: Luján de Cuyo, Mendoza Province, Argentina
Description: Allow some of the muscled-up aromas of rubber and churned earth to blow off and what's left are true blackberry aromas and seductive plum, berry, coffee and cola flavors. This properly captures the essence of Mendoza Malbec; it's dark and tannic but honest and healthy. Drink now into 2010.
Name: Enrique Foster 2004 Finca Castro Barros Reserva Malbec (Luján de Cuyo)

Description: If an intense style of Malbec is not your thing, then keep searching because this is intense in every way. The bouquet is dark and sun-drenched, with berry jam, leather and bacon aromas. The mouth shows huge blackberry, blueberry and black olive tastes, and the finish is warm and earthy, with espresso blackness. Shows every bit of its 14.9% alcohol but can handle it.
Name: Colomé 2006 Estate Malbec (Calchaquí Valley)

Description: Fruity and earthy, with sly, narrow flavors of blackberry and chocolate. This has the ripeness and power that one would expect from a high-end Malbec, but also a bit more finesse and natural “redness” than many heavyweights from Argentina. Hints of herbs, pine, lemon peel and mocha grace the structured finish.
Name: Ruca Malen 2004 Kinien Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Earthy, deep and true to its Uco Valley roots; this is a very good and fairly serious Malbec that doesn't try to overstep its natural limitations. It's not too extracted or oaky but instead delivers robust blackberry, plum and caramel flavors backed by a warm, mildly oaky finish with menthol and mocha. Drink now into 2010.
Name: Salentein 2005 Reserve Malbec (Uco Valley)

Description: An intense, forward style of Malbec. The nose oozes a mixture of mint, black-fruit extract and shoe polish, while the saturated palate is racy and just rich enough; the flavors of blackberry and plum are lively with coffee and mocha accents on the finish. A bit acidic and racy, but that won't hurt it if served with food.
Name: Trivento 2005 Golden Reserve Malbec (Mendoza)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: A single-vineyard, single-varietal wine, the Crawford Vineyard Malbec showcases the pleasure and power of the grape as it is being grown in Washington. Structurally it has the grip and precision of a Cabernet, with a pretty, lightly herbal side that runs more to green tea than to Cabernet's black olive. The fruit is tart and spicy, suggesting rhubarb, wild strawberry and cranberry, but as the wine opens up it puts on flesh and more layers.
Name: Camaraderie 2005 Crawford Vineyard Malbec (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This is a dark, sappy, saturated wine, and the power and grip of the fruit belies its claim of 12.9% alcohol. The Malbec is plenty ripe without being over-ripe, and the fruit retains a certain muscularity, along with a mélange of cherries, plums, rum-soaked raisins and coffee liqueur. Thoroughly delicious and captivating.
Name: Tagaris 2006 Alice Vineyard Malbec (Wahluke Slope)

Description: For several vintages running Broquel has nudged the border between very good and excellent, but as in years past the '06 is a touch tangy and racy, with black cherry, plum and berry flavors. It's bold, zippy and quite high-toned, but still it's very competent and held together.
Name: Trapiche 2006 Broquel Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Fruity and forward, but airing allows restraint and character to emerge. Still, this is a red-blooded red wine with racy fruit, plenty of freshening acids, pepper and bitter chocolate at the end. Best in late 2008 into 2009.
Name: Enrique Foster 2007 IQUE Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Woodsy spice, clove and chocolate announce the oak that is the lead factor throughout the wine. The nose is creamy and resiny green, with vanilla yogurt, plum and berry flavors coming next. Solid in terms of acidity and feel, but a little bit lactic due to the wood treatment.
Name: Dolce Stefania 2005 Reserva Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Blueberry with snap is the way to describe the bouquet on this fresh and spunky young Malbec. The flavors are sweet and intense, just like grapes off the vine. It doesn't offer much complexity but at the same time it doesn't taste confected or flawed in any way.
Name: Santa Julia 2007 Organica Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Earthy, spicy aromas soon give way to bramble, while the palate gives reasonably sweet but slightly tangy raspberry flavors. Some herbal leafiness enters on the finish, but not in an overbearing way. Good in a modest, basic way.
Name: Villa Viña 2005 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: A standard wine with ample berry and plum aromas supported by blackberry, plum and chocolate flavor. It's simple but smooth, with generic berry flavors, decent mouthfeel and length. Expect only the basics and it'll rank as good everyday wine.
Name: Zolo 2005 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Best Buy wines come in all shapes and sizes. This one settles at the bottom of the category, which doesn't mean that it doesn't have its charms, namely sweet and ready fruit and just enough acidity to keep it from being cloying. Keep in mind the price and young vintage when drinking.
Name: Santa Julia 2007 Malbec (Mendoza)

Appellation: Luján de Cuyo, Mendoza Province, Argentina
Description: Supposedly Doña Paula's top selection for 2005, and while the wine shows some earthy darkness and plenty of fruit on the bouquet it doesn't follow up with the mouthfeel or overall balance that it should. It's ripe for sure, but also aggressive, with a disjointed acid-to-tannin ratio and an almost syrupy mouthfeel.
Name: Doña Paula 2005 Selección de Bodega Single Vineyard Malbec (Luján de Cuyo)

Description: Purple, smoky and dense but beyond that it's regular. The palate is racy and medium deep, but the flavors are more superficial than interesting. Finishes quick, with coffee and bitter chocolate flavors.
Name: Caligiore 2007 Reserve Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Quite piercing on the nose, with unyielding cherry and hard-spice aromas. The palate is also intense, with saturated black cherry and raspberry flavors riding rough on a tight frame. Not the most friendly and easy Malbec.
Name: Trapiche 2006 Oak Cask Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: A little sharp and unfocused on the nose, but the palate is simple and juicy, with tangy red-fruit flavors backed by good acidity and solid tannins. Overall it's healthy and ready but sorely missing that one key ingredient: finesse.
Name: Tercos 2005 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Pungent, rudimentary berry aromas come across as candied, while the palate is very narrow and sweet. Drying on the finish due to wayward tannins; doesn't go beyond the ordinary. Imported by USA Wine Imports.
Name: Finca Los Maza 2005 Reserva Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Some wines in this range have it and others kind of struggle. This one seems to be fighting an uphill battle. The nose is unfocused and a little mulchy, while the flavors are jammy, sweet and basic. Tannin and acidity keep it cranking, but is that good?
Name: Antonio Cesar Cavalli 2006 White Pearl Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Average red juice with sweet, rubbery aromas and flavors that match. It's Malbec in its most simple state: raspberry and cherry distilled into a quaffable liquid. Chilling might help.
Name: Trapiche 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: A thick wine that doesn't bring the ripeness, sweetness and balance that's necessary. The nose is filled with milk chocolate, mint and cough syrup, while the palate is surprisingly tangy and sharp, with cranberry and wild raspberry flavors.
Name: St. Lucas 2005 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Big but scattered. The nose mixes incongruent aromas of green beans, chocolate and wood resin before transitioning to a palate of wood spice and generic berry fruit flavors. Too chewy, resiny and woody, and lacking harmony.
Name: Dolce Stefania 2005 Malbec (Mendoza)

Appellation: Luján de Cuyo, Mendoza Province, Argentina
Description: Having tasted and approved of many Chakana wines in recent years, I find this one way off the charts in the wrong direction. It's charred beyond repair, with gigantic berry and black coffee flavors that simply aren't that appealing. And it gets tougher and more sticky with airing. Note to winemaker: Back off the extraction and wood treatment.
Name: Chakana 2007 Malbec (Luján de Cuyo)

Description: Nothing about the El Fogón wines has been impressive. This Malbec, which should be the jewel of the portfolio, is a weak pretender with starchy, lean flavors of raspberry and apple skins. It has no body and a disjointed, buttery finish.
Name: El Fogón 2005 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Beware of funky labeled Malbecs because many don't have much to offer. Case in point, this candied, scratchy wine with wild, rampant fruit and not much else. Tastes like a jug wine.
Name: Ku Dé Ta 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: What a lush and spectacular New World Malbec. Buttery aromas of coconut and black fruits mix with herbs, mineral and char to create a near-perfect bouquet. The palate is saturated and balanced by great natural acidity, which frames the blackberry and herb flavors in excellent light. Meaty, textured, fruity and balanced: What more could you want? Drink now–2010. Imported by Baystate Wine Co.
Name: Viu Manent 2005 Viu 1 Malbec (Colchagua Valley)

Description: It's not often that we come across Chilean Malbec (Cot) with several years of bottle age, but this offers that and a little more. The nose is pure, with herbal hints and plenty of sauvage character. Roundness and depth give it length on the palate, which is endowed with solid berry flavors and proper savory accents. A wine with personality that's drinking perfectly right now.
Name: Viña Pérez Cruz 2003 Cot Reserva Limited Edition Malbec (Maipo Valley)

Description: Deep as always, but it steers clear of being too reduced and jammy. In what was a warm year, this Malbec has a mild granular, ultrarich quality that swallows some of the wine's spine and acidity. What's left is a rich, big red with coconut, vanilla, chocolate and just enough zest to keep it squarely balanced. With 7% Cabernet Sauvignon. Imported by Baystate Wine Co.
Name: Viu Manent 2006 San Carlos Estate Single Vineyard Malbec (Colchagua Valley)

Description: Fleshy and chunky, with plenty of leather, mint and malt courtesy of a hefty barrel influence. Definitely a saturated, big-boned style of Malbec, and while it has lots of berry at its core, there's also a savory quality to the wine that prevents it from being pure jam. Finishes slightly bitter, with espresso and dark chocolate accents. Imported by Baystate Wine Co.
Name: Viu Manent 2006 Reserva Malbec (Colchagua Valley)

Description: Nice on the nose, with mineral, crushed herbs and blackberry. The palate is equally good, with rich plum, cassis and blackberry flavors. This wine touches up against the high class with its rich mouthfeel and overall poise. Easy to recommend given its price. Imported by Atlanta Improvement Co.
Name: Viu Manent 2006 Secreto Malbec (Colchagua Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This is the winery's first varietal Malbec. Estate grown at the Bella Terra vineyard, it's an exciting debut, with floral scents over vivid purple fruit, and residual flavors of cured meat, smoke and pepper. About 14% Petit Verdot has been added to the blend.
Name: Ash Hollow 2005 Malbec (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Winemaker Michael Haddox is exploring unusual, emerging grape varieties in Washington State. This well-made Malbec is just the start, showing dried cherry fruit, graham cracker toast, and hints of stone and graphite. It's chewy and muscular, an interesting debut for the winery.
Name: Michael Florentino Cellars 2005 Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Initially a bit stiff and acidic, this young, tight Malbec opens to reveal tart cranberry, sour plum and red currant fruit. Its structure and underlying minerality are a bit reminiscent of a Loire Valley Cab Franc. This improves nicely after a couple of hours breathing time.
Name: Substance 2006 Mb Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This is 100% Malbec, so inky it is black in color. The flavors echo the color, with amazing density. Black fruits, black olives, smoke and spice are structured around thick tannins. A minute-plus finish adds licorice and mint; even after being opened for a full 48 hours this wine remained fresh and balanced. It's the first varietal Malbec ever from Walla Walla Vintners, but certainly one hopes it is not the last.
Name: Walla Walla Vintners 2005 Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: With Toso's basic 2006 Malbec being named our Best Buy of the Year for 2007, we find ourselves a bit pinned in judging this higher-priced Reserve Malbec from the same year. With the microscope turned up, however, we find a well-oaked wine with pencil-shaving aromas yielding to coconut and subtle black fruit notes. The palate is dense, structured and full of cherry, cassis and clove flavors. Composed for sure, with tighter acids and tannins than the aforementioned Best Buy champ.
Name: Pascual Toso 2006 Reserve Las Barrancas Vineyards Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Calling this big-boned brew potent may be understating things. This is brawny Tupungato Malbec in full armor. Early oak-driven aromas of hard cheese and char support muscular black fruit scents, while the palate is ripe and sweet as it offers blackberry and cassis flavors. Comfortable on the palate and well balanced overall.
Name: Finca Sophenia 2006 Synthesis Malbec (Tupungato)

Description: Very purple and expressive, with charred barrel aromas that border on burnt. Fortunately, the fruit below is quite healthy, but besides oozing blueberry and blackberry it's not overly defined or regal. Put this Patagonian Malbec into the category of vibrant and interesting and you won't be disappointed.
Name: Bodega Noemía de Patagonia 2006 A Lisa Malbec (Río Negro Valley)

Description: This plump, ripe Malbec is aggressive and jumpy on the nose, but the flavors of blackberries and chocolate are pure and positively represent what Argentina can do with value-priced Malbec. If you're not expecting miracles, this thick, textured wine may just win you over.
Name: Andean Sky 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Lots of heavily toasted oak sits atop the bouquet, and thus it's no surprise that the flavor profile runs a bit lemony and sharp. But give the wine time to unfold and you'll find a layer of pure blackberry mixed with notes of chocolate and coffee. Arguably too oaky but with good core qualities.
Name: Valentín Bianchi 2006 Famiglia Bianchi Malbec

Description: A conflicted and hence confounding wine. The nose is very oaky, but it's a pointed, almost piercing wood and clove bouquet. The wine is fierce in the mouth, with kicking tannins and acidity pushing bulldozer-like blackberry and bitter espresso flavors. With 6% Merlot, this Patagonian Malbec has its virtues but isn't as friendly as past vintages.
Name: Bodega Noemía de Patagonia 2006 J. Alberto Malbec (Río Negro Valley)

Description: Berry and earth on the nose are welcoming aromas, and overall this juicy, simple Malbec offers clean lines, a touch of complexity and good balance. The flavors channel berry and plum, and some vanilla runs shotgun. Not overripe or off base.
Name: Pannotia Vineyards 2005 Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Plenty of smoky oak on the nose, which leads to a mildly lactic influence on the palate. Other than that minor flaw, the wine settles to show resiny black fruit, firm tannins and a finish of vanilla and mocha. Grabby and extracted, but like so many Argentine Malbecs from 2005, it lacks the exuberant flavors and cushioned body that has made the categeory what it is today.
Name: Zuccardi 2005 Q Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Like many wines from this vintage, Melipal seems afflicted with 2005 blues. It has black plum and some woody char to chew on, but also saline and frisky tartness. Gets better with airing and will show best with food, but it's clearly a step down from prior years.
Name: Melipal 2005 Reserve Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Given the dearth of good Argentinean rosés on the market, this one from Cafayate (based on Malbec) is pretty tasty, balanced and interesting. The nose is succulent and not offputting, while the palate shows fresh red apple, cherry and length to the finish. Not complicated but racy and clean.
Name: Michel Torino 2007 Rosé Malbec (Calchaquí Valley)

Description: Juicy and jumpy on the nose, but not sour. The palate of this dark, almost red Malbec rosé is sweet and candied but also zesty due to pretty lively acids. It's not a stellar wine but it is full of berries and spunk.
Name: Chakana 2007 Rosé Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Jumbled and jumpy on the nose, which struggles to find itself. Time gives this wine a chance to strut, and while it doesn't ever find a great groove it does offer youthful plum and berry flavors followed by resiny tannins. A little too scattered and pocked to rate better.
Name: Fabre Montmayou 2006 Phebus Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: This mildly prickly, red-fruit dominated Malbec is perfectly drinkable. The nose is drying, while the palate shows red cherries and raspberry along with some forceful buttery oak. Reasonably long on the finish.
Name: Conquista de Argentina 2006 Malbec (Mendoza)

Appellation: Luján de Cuyo, Mendoza Province, Argentina
Description: Far less ripe and appealing than the 2004 version. The '05 comes out of the chute smelling malty and lactic; airing reveals strawberry milk notes, while the flavors struggle to express themselves. Sticky, oily and as if someone hit the mute button along the way. Where's the ripe, lush quality we've come to love about Argentinean Malbec?
Name: Luigi Bosca 2005 D.O.C Single Vineyard Malbec (Luján de Cuyo)

Description: Incongruous but with good intentions. The nose features cherry LifeSaver aromas but also hints of cheese and leather. The palate is modest and fairly acute as it delivers tangy, stretched-out plum and raspberry flavors.
Name: Calzo 2005 Malbec

Description: Certain Argentine wines have a rustic, foxy character to them that reminds us that winemaking isn't a factory-proven science. This fits the bill; it's murky and sharp on the nose, with brambly raspberry sitting in wait. Feelwise, it's a bit too piercing and choppy.
Name: Altocedro 2006 Año Cero Malbec (Mendoza)

Appellation: Luján de Cuyo, Mendoza Province, Argentina
Description: Decidedly brambly, with murky aromas mixed with rhubarb and pepper. The palate has a chunky, decent feel to it, but the flavors follow the nose: they are choppy and peppery. Meets all the standards of an acceptable wine, but could be much riper and more generous given its provenance.
Name: Luigi Bosca 2006 Finca La Linda Malbec (Luján de Cuyo)

Description: An aromatic dose of vinegar and rhubarb tempers expectations, and on the palate there's really nothing more than juicy, anonymous fruit and a hang-around finish. Adequate but no competition for a Mediterranean dry rosé.
Name: Andean Sky 2007 Rosé Malbec (Mendoza)

Description: Nothing more than cherry soda aromas to get it going. It's highly confected, with decent acidity its only saving grace.
Name: Finca Sophenia 2007 Altosur Rosé Malbec (Tupungato)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
